lead_paragraph: As the number of homeless people rises, a 1999 order meant to keep families with children from sleeping at an intake center in the Bronx forces many of them to forgo any rest at all.

headline.print_headline: Long Nights With Little Sleep  for Families Seeking Shelter
headline.main: Long Nights With Little Sleep for Homeless Families Seeking Shelter

snippet: As the number of homeless people rises, a 1999 order meant to keep families with children from sleeping at an intake center in the Bronx forces many of them to forgo any rest at all....
abstract: Record 59,373 homeless people in shelters in New York City has contributed to growing bottleneck of families at Prevention Assistance and Temporary Housing intake center in Bronx; situation for families is ironically exacerbated by 1999 law requiring city to provide temporary shelter overnight so that they do not have to sleep at the center; while temporary shelter is welcome relief, it requires families to shuttle back and forth between facilities, often with very little time to actually sleep, until housing is found.
